UT2k4 is a legendary multiplayer FPS that made Epic more then a studio that made the engine Deus Ex ran on. It featured fast paced deathmatch and amazing balance with it's weapons. What made UT2k4 also legendary was it's bot AI, which remains unprecidented in intelligence. UT2k4 also had a very large modding community and games like Red Orchestra and Killing Floor were mods for this game. Truly a delight to play and reminds me of a nice Saturday afternoon.

Fantastic game. Fast-paced, fun, requires skill, accuracy, a bit of thought, quick reflexes, and the ability to actually move around properly.  Dodge, wall-jump, and double-jump mechanics allow you to combine these in any order. They allow you to move quickly and be all over the place, making yourself hard to hit, and allow you to get across the map faster.  There are a multitude of weapons to be picked up off of the map, all of which are unique and have their own special functions, and alternate firing modes.  Hundreds of maps, most with great art-style, environments, geographical design, and music.  Being a game from 2004, the game still looks fantastic (better than many games today, unsurprisingly), and has a multitude of great bonus features.  -Press F11 and the game opens a built-in in-game music player that allows you to play any of your own, or in-game songs, instead of what the current map is playing. -In the audio options, there is a feature that enables built-in text-to-speech for the chat and IRC areas of the game, that way you don't miss a word as your head spins on a swivel, while you are caught up in the fast-paced shooting and battles, with no time to read.  There's a ton of game modes, Deathmatch, Bombing Run, Double Domination, Assault, Team Deathmatch, Capture the Flag, Vehicle Capture the Flag, Onslaught, and many others.  Get the game, play against bots (start off on just below masterful, trust me. Just BELOW Masfterful), and have some fun. Instant action and campaign, once you find a decent community, play some online. Do NOT play sniper camping, zark (especially), or ballistic weapons mods exclusively (24/7, or primarily). Also do NOT play DM-Rankin all the time. SUPPORT the servers that don't suck balls and have ACTUAL map rotation!

Another Unreal game that, for its time, was understated yet an innovation in technology, graphics and perhaps gaming AI. In retrospect, after hours of gaming on my old laptop, is the sort of game that you'd end up playing in phases, rather than throwing to dust after so long. This introduced me to gaming, and is worthy of so much more than it has been given. The new options added on from UT2003 have been spectacular, but perhaps have damaged the first-person shooter theme of it with the introduction of vehicles. Its successor, UT3, has considered this point well, but nonetheless fails to uphold the options on this game, with team selection and game controls. Despite some minor loopholes that emerge, it would still not be deservingly praised with a 'Game of the Decade' title.

This brings back so many memories... The first actual pc games i played were Unreal Tournament 2003 and Unreal Tournament 2004. These two games got me into pc gaming, not just because of the gratuidous violence or the simple way the game is laid out to you, it was the fact that they have almost endless replay value. Yea, the graphics dont look as good as they did back then but they were never developed for the extreme high definition displays we use today, But they still look amazing, especially since even if you have a lower end gaming rig, you can still play it with graphics maxed out.  The fact that Steam only has UT2004 and not UT2003 is a big letdown especially since they are missing a few other Unreal games, but with the supply of mods (if you know where to look and find them) adds even more fun, i didnt know about modding when i first played, so with the user created content floating out around the web...it basicly creates a whole new experiance . The Pro's Low end rigs should have little trouble if most of the hardware is from the last few years (i even tested it on my old compaq laptop that hated running games and got 30-50 fps on medium to high settings) Nearly unlimited replay value Multiplayer is still up//LAN//Dedicated server/hosted(pay-to-host)/listen servers(you host as you play) Tons of mod content ranging from skins, voice packs, maps, mutators, gamemodes and more. Includes unreal editor in game files so you can create content Custom Mappable Controls Setting to toggle gore for people with weak stomachs or children Plenty of weapons and vehicles for all the violent fun Singleplayer Voice Chat for those who know how to set it up Power-ups granting damage bonuses, invisibility, and more Play alone in instant action with bots and manipulate the ai difficulty ranging from a basic dummy ai that can get kills on you occasionally up to the God-Like ai that paints whatever is behind you with your blood (useful for practice) So much more that cant even be described  The Con's Often first time startup can be problematic with some higher resolution displays(simple fix by changing certain values in the games config, search google for fix) Mod content can sometimes be hard to find due to some file servers permanently archiving files or hard to understand install instructions Steam wont allow multiple instances of the game running (For example you open the game and set up a dedicated server, you cant open another instance of the game to play on your dedicated server unless you are smart enough to outsmart steam...hehe im not sharing my secrets..) Some resolutions dont always scale just right when using an HDTV as a monitor (lots of trial and error finding a resolution you are comfortable with)  Overall Unreal Tournament 2004 gets a 9 out of 10 *hops in scorpion, drives across map running down every enemy player/bot hops out to get in goliath, gets sniped . Respawns, grabs rocket launcher , Gets revenge*

Well, what makes UT2k4 unique from its obvious rival... -It was deathmatch, right? Not really, UT1 and Quake 3 were both perfect in their own ways, and the mechanics in UT2k4 are radically different from both. -...Okay... What about weapons? Close (Lightning Gun, Bio Rifle, Shock Rifle, Flak Cannon, Shield Gun) ...but no cigar (assault rifle, rocket launcher, grenade launcher, chaingun). -Map aesthetics/use of music/emphasis on environmental immersion over the thrill of blowing people up? ...That hit the nail on the head, but there is one more important thing. -Epic knew what made UT so great and learned from the blunder that was UT2k3 at the point where iD/Raven Soft was about to make the most fatal mistakes with Quake and DOOM? ...that took it way off topic... But I'll take it.  In all earnest, I'm a newcomer to the UT series, I started with UT3 on PS3 and then played UT4 on PC, but I really wanted to play UT2k4. It and UTGotY were like mythical beasts, you would hear about the fond memories gamers had when they experienced it... Only to realize that you were so late to the party and that age and circumstance have taken your ability to really, truly, fondly empathize with those tales. But you try to... And it sparks your desire to try to get into the artistic side of the game industry, if not the critical or narrative end...  Please, play this game, buy it on Steam, buy it from Amazon, dust it off from your collection. New or old. Maybe a lil' bot match to soothe the initial jitters, or dive into an Onslaught or CTF match online. I hope I muster the courage to eventually...

It's mainly a multiplayer first person shooter, but because it came out in 2004 the multiplayer community is unfortunately mostly dead.  There is a single player mode that consists of organized botmatches. You can form your own team of AI controlled bots and lead them to victory. Some of the maps have really inspired design and layout. For example there's one map where you're in a starfighter and you have to fight your way into a massive enemy mothership. Once inside you continue to progress on foot past numerous defenses. You finally make it to the enemy reactor core and blow it up, destroying the mothership. Awesome!  My main complaint about the bots is that there's very little variety in their behavior. Once you've figured out one bot you've figured out all of them. This hurts the replayability of the single player mode.  There's a huge variety of variant game types to keep things fresh. Everything from 'instagib' (one shot kills) deathmatches to classic Capture the Flag.   There's also an adrenaline 'booster' system; you earn or collect adrenaline points as you fight on a map. Once you reach 100 points you can use a special booster ability. Unfortunately how to use the booster system isn't well documented in the game, and many of the boosts aren't terribly useful. Also I found the boosts to be difficult to trigger at times, especially in the middle of an intense firefight, as you need to press a combination of keys in rapid succession.  The music is unobstrusive and nothing special. Graphics were probably cutting edge in 2004 but today they're just passable.  It's hard to recommend paying full price for a mainly multiplayer game with no multiplayer community. It might be worth getting on sale to play through the single player mode once, because as stated earlier some of the maps are really innovative.

I'm not exactly a fan of this iteration of the UT series, but there's one thing that I wish the upcoming new one could also have: team management in the Tournament campaign.  It's like a career mode in FIFA or something, but instead of playing football and managing a football team, you play UT. Buying/selling arena fighters, each with their own attributes and weapon preferences and then playing with the is the most fun this game offers. They can get injuries as well, which you need to treat, or else they remain on the bench. You can assign them positions on the field as well (cover you, defend/attack base, sweep etc.)  It's an amazing idea and very well suited for a game like UT. I hope this idea will be taken to the next level.

Though I was pretty much into shooters from the moment they started (Wolfenstein and Doom) Unreal Tournament 2004 solidified my love for shooters. This is one of the last stands of the classic arena based shooter. And thanks to the community you can enjoy thousands of custom characters, maps, game modes, vehicles, and weapons. No prestige grind, no rank ups, just pure unrealistic action in one of the greatest shooters of all time. If you enjoy Team Fortress 2, you owe it to yourself to at least give this classic a try.
